content.description:
I get the name, it hits you here and there with cheap shots when you don't expect it. Grainy hold sheds, lichen in the eyes from the ledge when you look up and grab, anchors just out of reach from the good stance, hard to clean because of the anchor arrangement, etc.... I've had better days weeding my garden, but if you insist....

You almost want to start from the ledge as for the others, but the bad holds are at bad angles and everything is dirty. It might be 11d there, or harder, but it is hard to say, it is so dirty. So you go a few moves up the corner to your left. The holds follow you, still too far left, so you go up the corner further... eventually you are at the level of the bolt. Clip that then back down a move and start there. You are now a few meters up the corner, reducing the remaining climbing to 20'-25', but at least you won't kill yourself and your belayer if you fall.

Continue up to the second bolt and stare at the anchors. They are way off to the right. The sequence is slightly left, but the rock above it is not really anchor worthy. Figure out eh interesting, but dirty sequence and get the top, then step right to clip the anchors.

The anchors are 2 bolts about 2' apart with a single split link parallel to the wall on each so that the rope is tough to thread or pull.

Have fun, if this is your sort of thing.
content.protection:
2 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor. It has old rusted stuff, but at least it is 3/8". The first bolt is high and above the big sloping corner. If you attempt to go directly up from the ledge and not up the corner, and you fall before clipping the first bolt, you and your belayer could end up going 30 yards down. Pray that one of you is in good enough condition to call 911 if you even have reception. The moves there are thin 11d and slightly dirty.

I did note that a 1.5" to 2.5" cam could be placed low and left into a crack at knee level of the belayer to improve the chances of a catch on that, but we had no such gear.
content.location: This is the left most bolted line on the wall, with 2 bolts and a 2-bolt anchor.

content.description:
This is the second to left route at the Arena. Short and stout, this route would probably be 12a at the Sport Park.

Anchor the belayer if you can, because there is some good fall potential clipping the second bolt. Or you can fall and hit your belayer in the head with quickdraws on your harness, like I did.

Fun moves, from tiny crimps and balancy edges, past some jugs and a hard mantle to a long reach, then more jugs.

Short and stout.
content.protection: Three quickdraws and a two-bolt anchor.

content.description:
"Poor-Nucopia," as in the lesser version of the classic

Cornucopia

up in the Flatirons. This route climbs the blank pane of rock between

Contender Direct

and Contender, joining both climbs for the upper face to the anchor. It has three new bolts of climbing and links into Contender for your fourth clip.

Pull on and move to a good rail, clip, bust into thin holds and stretch high for the second clip and move into the biz. A flat hold out right lets you clip the third bolt, then power up on better edges as you join Contender. I clipped the bolt on Contender as my fourth clip, then moved left where you can put a good Metolius black or red in a horizontal then unclip the bolt. Bust up on layback jugs, reel left along the rail and then climb the last two bolts of the Contender routes to finish on a semi-loose ledge with a relic Leeper-hanger anchor.

This is good, thin, old-school face climbing. Bring a pair of Megas and lycra tights. It is in the shade after 4 p.m. and is best on cold days.
content.protection: Five/six bolts plus Metolius black (#5) or red (#4).
content.location: This goes up the middle of the Arena/Contender Wall.

content.description:
This is the farthest right route at the Arena. It climbs egdes and slopey shelves up a black wall. Optional gear placement past the third bolt will make the climbing to the anchor safer.

It is stout for the grade but the easiest route at the crag.
content.protection:
Pass three bolts and a #1 Camalot/#2 Friend placement (see photo) en route to a two-bolt anchor.

Per

Gregger Man

: all the hardware has been upgraded to stainless 1/2" x 2.75" Power bolts w/ClimbTech hangers. There are now quicklinks with LocTite and rings at the top.

content.description: Begin just left of the pretty grey streak, and climb with some difficulty past the first bolt to a rail leading right. Clip the second bolt, then work up challenging bulges to another rail traverse right. Watch out for licheny feet when you clip. Head up and left towards the last bolt, and pull over onto a choosy ledge with a two bolt lowering anchor.
content.protection:
4 bolts and two clips for the anchor.

Stick clip the first bolt or anchor your belayer, as falling before clipping and pulling him/her off would mean you're gonna have a bad day.

Good clipping holds are found at bolts 2, 3, and 4, fortunately.
content.location:
Located between

Standing Eight Count

and

Pornucopia

, it's the third line from the left.
